excellent_study: yes, extremely large scale simple and straightforward. But hard to make further predictions based on species, provenances etc.

ifyouthink_no_why: not formal test, elevational proxy not rigurous

study_scale: 1 common garden, 24 provenances from all over Canada
growth_metric: growth anomalies (e.g. Spring frost ring, late frost ring, wood density fluctuations, etc.)
authorsthink_ALTteststatistic:: MAT in origin as related to adaptation to latitude/temperature
ifyouthink_no_why: provenance test, measured anomalies, not gsl treatment
missing_something_major: interesting idea of using wood anomalies. Proves adaptation (or maladaptation) by provenances across the range. Cool provenance study. Proves nothing related to GSL

study_scale: 2 forests, one in Spain, one in Russia
big_problems: only 2 locations, very few trees, simulated growth is unreliable (not only dubious model but unable to simulate growth adecuately even at year scale, let alone at intrannual), no validation whatsoever
missing_something_major: a measure for the end of the GS. For one species they measure leaf fall which is something but not even clear to me how this is measured in Pines and how important that is!

species_list: Populus tremuloides (dominant), Populus balsamifera, Corylus cornuta (understorey), other shrubs
gsl_metric: "the period when the forest was in leaf"
authorsthink_ALTteststatistic:: increased growth in year with earlier growing season, increased growth via warmer spring conditions
teststatistic_where: collection of many figures. Fig. 13 probably most relevant
ifyouthink_no_why: gsl measurement not described, no formal test, not enough years to test anything
big_problems: statistical powers is too low, sloppy descriptions, unclear definitions and tests
notes: very interesting approach of related rate vs. length and controlling for confounding factors

big_problems: cool study, sample size very small and they do not focus on gsl specifically, more in CSR theory and all that, pitty that their fig 5 is not really discussed
missing_something_major: the definition of growing season as duration of growth feels a bit weird (circular?)
notes: Authors focus on other questions. No discussion of gsl effects
